column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Morioka
#Text=Morioka ( 盛岡 ) is the capital of Iwate Prefecture , Japan .
#Text=Understand
#Text=For a traveller , Morioka is perhaps not high on any itinerary and is best known as a major transport hub for Tohoku .
#Text=From here , one can branch off on the Shinkansen towards Akita and some of the tourist towns on the Akita Shinkansen line .
#Text=It serves well as a stopover town on the way to either Akita or Hokkaido and there is enough to see and do for a day or two if you need somewhere to sleep or stock up on supplies .
#Text=Morioka can also be used as base for day trips to Kakunodate or some of the other small towns in the area .
#Text=Morioka is an ancient city ; it has been inhabited since prehistoric times .
#Text=You 're not likely to see much of its history , however , as it presents itself as much like any Japanese city of its size .
#Text=By train
#Text=Morioka is a major Shinkansen ( bullet train ) station on the Tohoku Shinkansen line .
#Text=It is also a major transit station for regular trains .
#Text=The most frequent Shinkansen services from Tokyo to Morioka are the all reserved Komachi ( こまち ) and Hayate ( はやて ) , which normally run coupled together as a single train .
#Text=The ride takes 2 1/2 hours at a cost of ¥ 13,840 each way , so you may want to consider purchasing a JR East Rail Pass or Japan Rail Pass beforehand .
#Text=Faster Hayabusa ( はやぶさ ) services make two daily round-trips between Morioka and both Tokyo and Aomori , complementing the other services .
#Text=Fares for the Hayabusa are slightly higher ( ¥ 14,340 from Tokyo ) .
#Text=The Japan Rail Pass and JR East Rail Pass are valid for travel on the Hayate , Komachi and Hayabusa .
#Text=On the other hand , rail passes will only cover the basic fare if you are willing to try out the premium first class seating on the Hayabusa called " GranClass " .
#Text=To use " GranClass " the limited express and GranClass fare has to be paid ( ¥ 14,640 from Tokyo ) .
#Text=Without a rail pass , " GranClass " costs ¥ 22,830 between Tokyo and Morioka .

#Text=Morioka is a good option for a stopover if you are travelling by train to either Hakodate or Akita during peak times where it can sometimes be impossible to get a seat to your final destination .

#Text=Depending on where you are going , you will be allocated a seat on either the Hayate or Komachi , which travel together as a joined train until Morioka where they split off to go to Shin-Hakodate and Akita respectively .
#Text=If you are only travelling as far as Morioka you can be allocated a seat on either part of the joined train .

#Text=It 's then possible to spend the night in Morioka and get an early train in the morning to the place you want to go , or to jump on a local train if you 're only going so far as an intermediate Shinkansen stop between Morioka and Akita or Shin-Hakodate , for example if you 're going to Kakunodate .
#Text=By bus
#Text=An overnight bus service , the Rakuchin , runs twice nightly from Tokyo Station to Morioka ( about 7 1/2 hours , ¥ 7,850 one way ) .
#Text=Other companies offer cheaper , less comfortable rides for as little as ¥ 5,000 .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Morioka is a small enough city to walk around .

#Text=The furthest you 're likely to want to go is the Morioka Castle site which is about a 30 minute walk from the front of the train station over the steel arch bridge and through the central business district .

#Text=You can otherwise get the bus to the castle site ( below ) , but the walk through the city is quite pleasant , though can be slippery , snowy and just plain cold in winter and unpleasantly hot and humid in summer .
#Text=From the station , the easiest and safest way to into the city proper is to use the underground tunnels from the station which go underneath the bus station and the main road .
#Text=This can be slightly confusing at first for people who cannot read Japanese signs and is not wheelchair accessible .
#Text=There is a wide and flat walking trail along the Kitakami river that makes for a pleasant walk or a good jogging spot with nice views of Mt Iwate .
#Text=It 's about a five minute walk from the front of the station , walking straight ahead to the steel arch bridge and then taking the stairs on either side of it down to the river .
#Text=By bus
#Text=There is a large and sometimes confusing bus centre at the front of the station .
#Text=Watch where you 're going here as buses come from all directions while you 're trying to cross the short distance to the shops in front of the station .
#Text=Sometimes there will be a security guard who will stop traffic for you to cross .

#Text=Iwateken Kotsu bus operates the Den-Den-Mushi Bus ( でんでんむし、Japanese for ' snail ' , which seems a strange name for a bus ; it 's easy to spot with a picture of a multi-coloured snail on the side of each bus ) which encircles the city central area starting from Morioka main station via castle park and Bus Center .
#Text=The cost is ¥ 100 per ride , and run every 10 min both clockwise and anti-clockwise during daytime .
#Text=For such a low price it is a good way to get your bearings if you 're new to Morioka .
#Text=See
#Text=Morioka Castle ( 盛岡城 ) , ☏ +81 19-639-9057 .
#Text=Morioka Castle was built in the 16th century by Nanbu Nobunao , the first daimyo of the area .
#Text=The castle was used as a residence during its heyday until it was dismantled during the Meiji Period .
#Text=The area was converted into a park in 1906 and is known today as a popular place to see cherry blossoms in the spring .
#Text=It is also very pretty in winter when the snow falls on the varied landscape and old castle walls , but it can be slippery and you can expect to trudge through thick snow .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Morioka History and Culture Museum ( もりおか歴史文化館 ) .
#Text=Morioka Museum of Great Predecessors ( 盛岡市先人記念館 ) , ☏ +81 19-659-3338 .
#Text=A museum with rotating exhibits about people who have been influential in Morioka . ¥ 300 .
#Text=Nansho-so ( 南昌荘 ) .
#Text=Morioka City Science Center ( 盛岡市子ども科学館 ) , ☏ +81 19-634-1171 .
#Text=A children 's museum with a educational science exhibits and a planetarium .
#Text=Museum entrance is ¥ 200 , Planetarium is ¥ 300. .
#Text=Hoonji ( 報恩寺 ) .
#Text=Contains 500 rakan statues .
#Text=Oyakuen Garden ( 御薬園 ) .
#Text=The garden was originally constructed in the early Edo Period as an herb garden and was later converted into a garden for the local lord .
#Text=It became a villa in 1908 until the buildings around the garden were turned into a museum .
#Text=Today the garden is a popular spot to see autumn foliage .
#Text=Takuboku Shinkon House ( 啄木新婚の家 ) .
#Text=The Takuboku Shinkon House is the former residence of Takuboku Ishikawa , a famous local poet .
#Text=He lived here as a newlywed with his wife albeit only for less than 3 weeks . Free .
#Text=Iwate Prefectural Art Museum ( 岩手県立美術館 ) . 9:30AM-6PM .
#Text=Shiwa Castle ( 志波城 , shiwa-jō ) .
#Text=Reconstruction of an ancient jōsaku fort ( 城柵 ) .
#Text=Former Nakamura Residence ( 旧中村家住宅 ) .
#Text=HARA-KEI Memorial Museum ( 原敬記念館 ) , ☏ +81 19-636-1192 . 9AM-5PM .
#Text=The former home of Takashi Hara which has been converted into a museum .
#Text=Takashi Hara was a Morioka native who served as Prime Minister of Japan from 1918 to 1921 .
#Text=He is also known for being Japan 's first Christian Prime Minister .
#Text=The building contains documents and personal possessions .
#Text=Fukazawa Kōko Nonoha Art Museum ( 深沢紅子野の花美術館 , fukuzawa kōko nonoha no bijutsukan ) , ☏ +81 19-625-6541 . 10AM-6PM .

column3: 深沢紅子野の花美術館

column1: #Text=A Morioka native , Fukazawa was a 20th century painter of European-style art .
#Text=Morioka Hachimangu ( 盛岡八幡宮 ) .
#Text=Sixteen Arhats ( 十六羅漢 ) .
#Text=Daijiji ( 大慈寺 ) .
#Text=Ishikawa Takuboku Memorial Museum ( 石川啄木記念館 , ishikawa takuboku kinenkan ) .
#Text=A famous tanka poet who was born here in the Tamayama district .
#Text=The museum has information and displays about him and his poetry .
#Text=Iwate University Museum and Botanical Garden ( 岩手大学ミュージアム , iwate daigaku myūjiamu ) , ☏ +81 19-621-6082 . 10AM-3PM .

column3: 岩手大学ミュージアム

column1: #Text=A museum established by the university with a nice botanical garden outside .
#Text=Morioka Zoo ( 盛岡市動物公園 , morioka-shi dōbutsuen ) .
#Text=The Morioka Zoo a great place to check out the animals in a peaceful surrounding .
